text: Uh well, my name is Andrew Joy and uh
welcome to my talk, Network Prediction,
Replications, Crystal Ball. Uh just
quickly, a little bit about me. I've
been in the games industry about 18
years and using Unreal Engine for about
11 of those years. Uh I mostly do
contract work, so the work tends to vary
a lot and I've kind of touched on a lot
of systems in my time, but I also work
on an open world survival game, which uh
given the genre touches on a lot of
systems. Uh so I've become a bit of like
a programming generalist uh by force.
But every time I come back to Unreal
Fest, I seem to be giving a talk on
replication. And today will be no
different uh because today's concept is
network prediction and reconciliation.
So what do I mean by that? Well, I'm
going to illustrate with this timeline
here. Up the very top, we have client
network events and down the bottom, we
will have server network events. And
let's just focus on the network part for
now. So, Unreal Engine uses a pretty
standard server authorative replication
model. Meaning that if you want to make
changes to the server authorative state,
you have to request that on the server
and then wait for the change to be made.
So, for example, if our client wants to
fire a gun, they will have to fire the
gun and then request that from the
server.
uh that can take an arbitrary amount of
time to reach the server based on
network conditions. Then the server will
potentially spawn the bullet and then
replicate the bullet back to each
client. This introduces quite a lot of
roundtrip time and this is lag as you
know it in uh in video games and the way
around it is using a system called
network prediction. With network
prediction, we aim to immediately
cosmetically simulate client inputs on
client side as they happen to try and
mask this lag. So, for example, we would
immediately spawn a bullet. We would
still need to communicate with the
server to change the author of game
state and to spawn the bullet on every
other client. But for our purposes, it's
as if we don't have lag at all. It's
kind of magic. However, it opens us up
to a couple of problems. So, if we just
look at the client firing the gun, and
spawning the bullet, what happens if at
the same time they get stunned, maybe
another player comes in, throws a stun
grenade, very sneaky, and they can no
longer fire their gun. They won't
actually know that they got stunned
until that is communicated back to them
an arbitrary amount of time later, and
they will still go ahead and fire the
gun and spawn the bullet, thinking that
they can. When that message hits the
server, the server will say, "You can't
fire a gun while you're stunned," and
discard it. So these red events just
won't happen at this point. We have
desync. So the client has a bullet
traveling along through space. The
server has no bullet and every other
client also has no bullet. The way to
fix this is with reconciliation. So
pretty much correction or adjustment for
our mistakes. Uh in this case, the
server would have to bounce back a
response and say, "No, you can't fire
the bullet. Go ahead and undo it." So we
would roll back the bullet by
immediately destroying it, undoing all
of its visual and audio effects and
trying to pretend that it never
happened. Obviously the client would
still see it for a moment. We can't
actually like roll back time, but uh we
for all intents and purposes we we have
fixed our desync. Uh this is still even
though the client may notice it, it's
still very preferable to just uh not
having network prediction at all. It's
kind of required.
So quick takeaways for today's talk. I
just very briefly covered general
network prediction concepts. Next, I'm
going to talk about how the Unreal
Engine implements network prediction for
you to use in your own game or other
project. Uh the UN after this point, I
hope that you'll have kind of a basic
understanding of how it all fits
together. But from there, we're going to
move over and look at the mover
component because the mover component
implements network prediction but
enhances upon it in ways that will
hopefully give you an advanced
understanding of Unreal Engine's default
network prediction. Also, the mover
component is really cool. Uh, and I kind
of want to sell it a little bit, but I
promise it's mostly about network
prediction. And then finally, I'm going
to talk about how my own game,
Planetation, uses both of these and some
pitfalls that you will probably run into
when you first begin on this journey.
So, first, how Unreal Engine uses
network prediction. There's three
flavors of network prediction in the
engine. Uh, the first is gas gameplay
ability system has its own built-in
network prediction. Uh, it's it's really
good, but if you want to step outside of
gas, you you it makes it pretty
difficult to kind of use gas's network
prediction. Next is the CMC, the
character movement component. And this
also has built-in network prediction,
but again, the moment you step outside
of the CMC and gas, you're on your own.
It's very hard to use their network
prediction. Finally, we have the NPP.
And this is the topic of today's talk,
the network prediction plugin. This is a
generic base layer of network prediction
that you can use to integrate into your
own project for your own purposes. Uh
but you might be wondering why don't the
CMC and gas use the MPPP.
The reason is just they're all very old
and trenched systems and they're very
hard to move at this point. But
thankfully there is a new kit on the
block, the mover component uh which is
hopefully going to end up replacing the
CMC. Fingers crossed because it is
awesome and it is built on top of the
NPP. There is no gas replacement which
is fine because gas is awesome. But this
might be a use case for you if you have
your own action system or any number of
other systems. We use the MPPP
internally for a bunch of purposes.
So how does the MPP work? Well, if we
look at our earlier example, we were
doing everything on the game tick, which
means everything is dictated by the
frame rate. uh we sometimes might be
doing things 12 milliseconds apart then
20 then 100 if there's a hitch and
furthermore the client and the server
and every other client will have a
different frame rate. This makes it very
unpredictable trying to determine when
things will happen and sometimes even
the order that they will happen. So the
MPP the first thing it does is you move
to a fixed tick system meaning there is
a predictable uh configurable time in
between its state changes. in this case
50 milliseconds, but it's actually a lot
shorter than that. Uh, and it's also
configurable. So, in this case, we would
fire the gun for demonstrative purposes.
We'd spawn the bullet on the next frame,
on the next fixed tick. But we can go a
step further than this, and we can
actually use numbered prediction frames,
index prediction frames. And the idea
here is we're now firing the gun on
frame 100 and then spawning the bullet
on frame 101. This makes it really easy
to determine, okay, something's going to
happen in three frames time or something
happened three frames ago. But even more
importantly, it lets us stagger our
servers prediction frames like you can
see up here in the example. So then as
we fire the gun on client side on frame
100, we are also firing the gun on
server side on frame 100. Now we have a
matching history between client and
server. And this makes it way easier to
determine if we are out of sync and how
we are going to reconcile that mistake.
Speaking of reconciles, how do we add
that uh to a fixed tick system? Well, if
we take our earlier roll back and snap
all of the events to the fixed tick,
we've moved everything except the green
stunned event on client side. The blue
stunned event on server side has been
added to frame 99. But where do we put
the client stunned event when it
receives it? we would roll back and
inject it back into frame 99. And then
when we replay our history, we determine
we couldn't actually fire that gun. We
still have to do the same technical roll
back of the bullet, destroying it and
undoing all of its side effects. But the
major difference now is our history uh
has also uh been updated to match the
server. Our history now uh is as if we
had never fired the gun or spawned the
bullet in the first place. And this is
very important.
So, you can turn on the network

Speaking of that, I want to warn people

and you'll have a head start when you do

I know how to find that. So without
further ado, the five most important
types in the NPP. The first is the
network prediction component which is
kind of a quality of life system in this
in this case. It does all of our

stored on the component. If you can't

just use the proxy. You would just need
to do a little bit more manual work. If
we look at the source code, you can see
that the network prediction component is
abstract, meaning you you have to

it it it is also an actor component.
This might be one of the reasons why you
can't use it yourself and would want to
just use the proxy. The proxy is stored
here as a replicated U property, meaning
that the authorative prediction state
will be replicated down to each client.
And there are other ways that the client

types, you might notice that even though

they actually make up each of our

but let's have a little look at the

serialized function which is required
for replication purposes and the
two-string function which is required
for debugging. All three of our types
the input command, the sync state and
the orc state require these two
functions. So you will be seeing them a

at the end so no stress about like
taking photos feel free but yeah it it
will come back I promise. Uh let's look
at the sync state. So the sync state is
pretty much the current state of the
simulation. The client and the server
will be modifying this over time in
parallel doing their best to keep them
in sync. But if the client detects that
it has desynced from the server it will
reconcile its state to match the server.
This mock sync state contains again just
a single float the total value that we
have accumulated over time to this point
of the simulation.
Again it contains net serializ and two
string. We've seen them a lot and it
adds should reconcile. This function
determines whether or not there has been
a desync and a you know reconcile should
happen. And then the interpolate
function that it also adds controls how
it brings the client back into sync with
the server. You should, you might
remember that the earlier example of
rolling back the bullet was a single
frame. You you destroy the bullet, you
undo its effects immediately. That's not
technically required even though you can
do it here. Generally, we want to
interpolate back to our server sync
state. So then the the player is less
likely to notice that we made a mistake
in the first place. We always want to
kind of smooth it out. Last, we're going
to look at the orc state or the
auxiliary state. This is a bit harder to
get your head around, but you can kind
of understand it as a sync state that
contains data that rarely needs
reconciling. It's kind of a it's kind of
an optimization. Uh the idea is whenever
a reconcile happens, the more data we
have to reconcile, the more work we have
to do. And in this case, it contains a
single float multiplier on how much
input is being added to our simulation.
In a movement example, for example, this
might contain your maximum movement
speed. Again, a value that must be kept

have to tell you that I lied. There is

type. And I'll I'll let me explain how

a single function simulation tick. It
contains no properties. It doesn't
inherit from anything. And all this does

In this mock example, we set our new

scaled by delta time. Even though this

we can hardcode this, the uh interval is

only job of the prediction model

this is the last type. This is how it

might notice the first time we have

if you remember earlier we have to

this is just our custom prediction

So, quickly to recap that, because it
was a lot, there are seven important
types in the MPP. the network prediction
component and proxy which do all of the
running of the simulation. The input
command sync state and the orc state

simulation type which is responsible for
generating new prediction frames. And
finally the model definition which tells
our system about all of our custom
types. But something here is missing and
that is what actually calls this

doesn't inherit from anything. This is
not a virtual override. This is uh
called as a template concept. So I won't

Well, this one's a little bit special.

first what is a movement base? Because

that we have this cool platform and then

Maybe it's a spaceship we're staying on

roams about. If it moves, one of two
things will happen to our character. If
we're using unbased movement, the
character will be left behind and
eventually fall off when the platform
moves out from under it. But if we are
using based movement, the character will
move with it and then perform its
movement in addition to the platform's
movement uh afterwards.
There is a problem here though. The
movement base in the mover component is
stored inside of the mover default sync
state. And this entire sync state needs
to be able to replicate. So if we are
standing on top of a base that cannot
replicate, then we will see based
movement on our end and everyone else
will see unbased movement because there
is no reference to whatever base we're
standing on. We end up with movement
desync.
This generally is easy to fix for
probably most people's games in this
room. You can either turn off based
movement entirely or you can just make
sure that everything you can stand on is
a replicated actor. But we have a kind
